comments.commentBody: I agree that a lot of Kobe's display seemed like a sham, and I've been waiting for him to move on for several years. Still, those last three-pointers were impressive, and I don't think it was foreordained that the Lakers would win. That was kind of a miracle.
It's interesting how few people have any respect for our legal system.
Well, it sure would be nice if we all would work together for a common goal, but we'd all rather die apart than live together.  (Climate change is dangerous to ignore.)
I can't imagine why anyone with presidential ambitions and a law degree from Yale would choose the Children's Defense Fund as a springboard to the presidency.

Cmon Susan, it's for the same reason high school kids get involved in clubs or community activities- because it looks good on their college applications. She certainly didn't make a career out of her time at CDF; it was just a segue into future positions with considerably more political power.

We are not "swallowing the Republican line". We are reflecting and commenting on her record. There is more than enough there to justify our collective mistrust of her motives and intentions. If you disagree with us, that's one thing - but stop  dismissing our concerns as nothing more than some sort of infantile zombie mindset.

I think our country faces a lot of important challenges and Senator Sanders has focused attention on many of them. He has also energized many young voters and progressives, and hopefully they will get to the polls in November and in 2018, even if Senator Sanders is not the nominee.

I am not as convinced by his narrative and his solutions. As an example, mass incarceration started long before the Clinton administration and is a huge problem at the state level. As another example, the long decline of manufacturing started long before NAFTA, or TPP, or most-favored nation status for China. As another example, a $15 minimum wage for the entire country (as opposed to a smaller increase or indexing to inflation) would be a disaster for young workers, marginally-skilled workers, students, and part-timers. As a last example, there is a big difference between making college free versus making college affordable.

Putting aside Senator Sanders, I am troubled by how many of his supporters have decided that Secretary Clinton is untrustworthy (swallowing the Republican line), or corporate, or conservative. We're talking about a Yale law grad who went to work for the Children's Defense Fund, not some Ivy League millenial who went straight into Wall Street finance to make a fortune.

"Although current polling suggests Sanders would defeat Trump or Cruz in a general election by a wider margin than Clinton, ..."

And Kasich, who beats Clinton.

A perspective I believe has been missing in the Democratic campaign analysis is the way HRC has been pretty much handling Sanders with kid gloves, not attacking him personally. I believe this is because HRC is reasonably confident she will gain the party's nomination and wants to unify the party for the general election. Meanwhile Sanders is going negative, feeding off years of innuendo against HRC's character.

Although current polling suggests Sanders would defeat Trump or Cruz in a general election by a wider margin than Clinton, this is before Sanders has been sufficiently scrutinized by the Right. We are have already begun to notice Sander's ideas lack credible detail. Do we really believe the Republicans will conduct a general election campaign based on policy debate? We have already seen the Republicans attack President Obama with dog whistles related to race, religion, socialist associations, etc. Imagine what will be done to Bernie. At least we know HRC's skeletons and she would still defeat any Republican in a general election. Sanders would be fresh meat for the Republicans and they would take the opportunity to impugn his character and identity on multiple levels. It won't take long for the dog whistles to come out and take the shine off Sanders. I believe the Republicans fear Hillary and are praying for a Bernie upset. Starry-eyed liberals, for whom they hold contempt, seem prepared to deliver their wish.

Oh It can be done, but it still has to be paid for, and therein lies the problem.
The UC system was free until the Free Speech movement which so agitated St. Ronnie that he was able to convince the voters, the universities were the creators of Socialist, Communist revolutionaries, which in that day were much feared. H was able to get the legislature to cut funding for those radical professors, and make students pay. Now the citizens of California have forgotten about the free colleges and want them paid for by the students. Worse yet the state universities have gone to associate professors and part timers, cutting costs even more. We are losing our core of top grade professional educators.
Hillary is running against Bernie. Bernie is asking for the transcript not Trump. By the way, this kind of attitude by Hillary is why she used a private email server - to hide facts from you and me.

The people "need to know that their President is not a crook." Richard Nixon

HRC has learned nothing about the electorate since her days working on the Watergate committee.

"The Clintons evoke many feelings, but the strongest is of déjà vu. And in Hillary’s case each new controversy or scandal or pseudo-scandal—we’re never sure— arrives trailing gusts of previous ones. We—and she—have been here before."

Excerpt from http://www.bloomberg.com/politics/features/2015-11-05/how-richard-nixon-...

After 45 years of political dysfunction culminating in a government that looks like the governance going on in Belgium and to different degrees in the rest of the EU, public protests that are becoming more violent (at least here in Europe) and the revelations of what our leaders and the 1% are up to (Wikileaks, Panama Papers, Snowden) the people will get the change they're demanding. They always have. They're done with neoliberalism and cowboy capitalism. The question remains, will the transition be violent/reactionary (as has happened in much of our history) or will it be in the style of say the Czech "Velvet Revolution".

Personally I see the elitists of both parties circling their wagons. Not a good sign.

Everybody's a mind-reader -- they all know Hillary's thought and motives. Funny, their Tarot cards always seem to line up perfectly with their previously held opinion of her.

You're missing the point, Bill. She is running against Sanders now, but after that, she'll be running against the GOP. With the way Republicans have spent the last thirty years picking apart every tiny innocuous detail of her life and spinning it as evil, she'd be plain stupid to hand them more potential material. Do you even care whether a Democrat wins?
If Clinton wants to reunify Democrats, there is an easy path. Release the transcripts.

I'd say that has about zero chance of every happening.

If Bernie would accept that as a compromise to drop out of the race, it would have happened months ago -- and there would have never been this level of angry debate between the two of them.

You could have argued in 2008 that Obama would offer HIllary the No. 2 spot -- but that didn't happen, did it? How often has a Presidential candidate ever offered the VP spot to a really serious contender who had threatened his nomination?
You are completely crazy to think that either candidate would serve under the other; completely laughable.
It's not going to be both of them on the same ticket.  They're both too old, just for starters.

In any case when all is said and done the final outcome of the two dynamic campaigns of Clinton and Sanders will produce the Democratic ticket described below:

Hillary and Bernie as VP.
or
Bernie and Hillary as VP.

Democrats will support either one of these two outcomes and it is to be hoped that Independents will do so as well.
There is strength in diversity.
Either way the above final result will be unbeatable in the general election.

So rest easy. And have a nice day.

From polls it seems like there aren't too many of them, but the ones that exist are extremely vocal.

Frankly I don't want people like that in my party anyway.
Our best hope is for Bernie to get the democratic nomination. Better still:  Hillary should bow out.That would make for a whole lot of unifying.
It's Bernie Sanders or The Donald for me. I will not be forced to vote for Hilary Clinton.

If Sanders' ultimate goal was to come together behind the Democratic candidate, even if he were not the victor, he would have run a different campaign.

Our only hope is that the "Bernie or bust"-ers are not as numerous as their shrill presence on social media would have us believe, and that most Sanders supporters will indeed back Clinton, in spite of the belligerent, aggressive tone his campaign has taken.
Agreed. we need a third party

The US doesn't have a Parliament. Some very prominent Founders didn't like or want parties (Washington, Jefferson), but they evolved. There is nothing in the law or Constitution that requires them. Anyone who wants to run for any office can run as an independent.

Recent history has shown that this does not very often lead to winning an election, however.

What needs to come - in the long run - is the dismantling of the two-party system. Before one stresses "unity" one must ask: unity behind what? Why are voters expected to fall in line simply because there is no better option?

Election without meaningful choice is elected dictatorship. It's as simple as that.

Six figures? LOL -- in most of Ohio, you can buy a decent home in the mid FIVE figures. Six figures will buy you a very nice house here.

To go from $8.10 to $15 in one year is nearly doubling the minimum wage. Nobody seems to care how that affects businesses, or even things like what you pay the baby sitter -- or what an elderly person would have to pay for home health care. It would be devastating and inflationary.

Also it does nothing to help the middle class. Only a small number of jobs pay the absolute minimum -- even McD now pays $9 an hour.

The real problem is MIDDLE CLASS JOBS -- the kind that require a college degree -- that TODAY pay $15 an hour....they won't go up, because most such workers are "exempt" (with phony titles like "manager" when they don't manage anyone).

Nobody on the left is looking at "Europe" for the effects of this kind of thing -- though they worship "Europe" -- where in France, the unemployment rate for workers under 30 is something like 22% (much worse in Italy, Spain, Greece!). That's because nobody wants to hire inexperienced workers and pay them the same as mature, experienced workers.

Here's a tip for you. $8.10 an hour will not buy you a home in a neighborhood with good schools. low six figure houses cost too much per month. $8.10 per hr for 40 hours is only: $324 per week.
That's only $1296 per month - subtract 7.65% for FICA $99.14 leaves you with -
$1196.86. Do the math!

I had a small store with part-timers, whom I made sure got some hours year-round, especially in summer when their school district paychecks stopped. I'm not Walmart or McDonald, with big profits and cash flow for padding. I could do it at $10, but $12 was a huge stretch during our slower season, and at $15, I would have had to cut back hours to just rush times.

We did everything aboveboard -- workers comp, witholding, TDI, but I still had to pay the store's rent, and I lived lean,but I can't live on air. I used to be able to raise prices to make up the difference, but these days, people can touch the merchandise that I paid for, using the space I rented -- and then go buy the same product online for less than I could afford to sell it at, especially because I had to charge sales tax. We never had much cash money -- gotta keep putting stock on the shelves.

$15 is necessary in expensive urban areas, but many parts of the country, $12 would help the employees without putting the cost out of reach for the business. Not every employer is a fat cat, and some of us are pretty skinny.

There are sound economic rationale why there should not be a national minimum wage at 15.  As an example, Ohio minimum wage is $8.10 in 2016, and  homes can be had  low six figures in neighborhoods with good schools.  If nothing else, an increase in minimum wage to $15 will make it that much harder for young men and women, not to mention other long-term unemployed in OH get a job.

Glass Steagall wouldn't have prevented the 2008 meltdown and won't make the financial system more stable. Every time Bernie mentions it I cringe because it reveals his limited understanding of financial regulation.
Where is the detailed replacement for Glass-Steagall Clinton has assured us will be better than the original?  On this one she sounds kind of like Don...trust me, it'll be incredible!

@RLS - lose their jobs!?  Because he has the authority to fire them?  Because  younger people have historically shown up in huge numbers for midterm elections? It is an inconvenient fact for many sanders supporters that millions of republicans also inhabit this country and will be voting against your revolution.

The attribution of revolution to Sanders is overblown rhetoric, clearly. The term is employed by candidates of all stripes on occasion and it has been fed by media to steer the narrative away from his central message, which is simply to reverse oligarchic trends in American politics. Citizens United and unregulated, speculative banking have been wings of a recent corporatist, oligarchic 'revolution' enacted upon the public without consent. It's basically been running wild for well over a decade, thanks to a leadership too much owned by their patronage.

As for free stuff, ask a corporation (since they are people, after all) how much free goodies and tax-free profit it's been able to accrue in the 21st century. The answer might put a damper on your commentary for quite a while.

With all due respect, you are delusional if you think the bully pulpit will be an effective method.  The congressional districts have been gerrymandered to completely protect many of the seats -- there is NO danger that they will lose their jobs by opposing Sanders. In fact it will be the only way for them to keep their jobs.  Yes, we need to change the makeup of Congress. Many Democrats, MANY millennials, and a lot of the people voting for Sanders do not vote in the off presidential elections OR for any candidate other than him (see recent Salon article on WI election).  I beg you and all of the Sanders supporters to resolve this problem.

Bernie has captured the attention of young voters because he is promising a "revolution".   He doesn't know how he will implement this revolution or how he will pay for it.  But it does sound exciting and maybe you will get something free!

I'm voting for Hillary; but if she loses the nomination, I'll vote for Bernie.

As a former Republican, I'd like to see every Democratic voter make the same pledge--to stick with the party that needs to win.

If not, we'll be stuck with President Trump--or even worse--President Cruz. And I truly believe that would be dangerous for America and for the entire world.

what "Real' approcahes" does she have?  More like status quo, support your corporations approaches.  No changes, more of the same stuff that got the country where it is today. Besides, she won't get anything done if the Repubs. retain control of congress.

I think Hillary Clinton shows clear and focused thinking with real approaches to solving some our worst problems. If Bernie Sanders becomes the candidate he will get my support...right now I support Mrs. Clinton as the better and more realistic candidate.

Thank you for making your excellent point.
Clinton should not be attacked for taking on the complexities of difficult issues.

Using your reasoning, the whole state of NY should not have a uniform minimum wage when it is finally and actually at $15. Lots of tiny towns where rents are low in upstate NY, right?

Same with CA. Even though CA has some of the most expensive housing in the country, there are pockets of poverty.

Money is part of our cultural ecosystem. Like all ecosystems, applying a uniform $15 to the whole country would require, yes, that some places have bigger adjustments.

It's not like any state or city has made the min wage $15 immediately. It is still phasing in in Seattle. CA waits until 2022 for $15.

With a uniform country-wide minimum wage, there will be adjustments in the economic climate, some migration for jobs and housing, just as there always have been. but humans working for $15 will have some dignity.

And, I need to keep saying this, no way I will ever vote for Hillary. I will write in Bernie if he does not get the dem nomination, which I think he will, in spite of the NYTimes doing their utmost to stack the deck in favor of Killary.

"She cheers states like New York that have raised their minimum wage to $15 an hour, as Mr. Sanders wants to do nationally. But she favors a national minimum of only $12, not $15. Why? Her explanation is that a $15 wage could hurt workers in places where wages are generally lower and that the matter should be left to local governments. This contorted position makes her vulnerable to accusations that she’s less than passionate about meeting the needs of low-income families or is being pressured by special interests on the issue."
Your criticism of Hillary Clinton's stance on the federal minimum wage is simplistic to the point of dishonest. There is nothing "contorted" about recognizing cost of living varies by region. Clinton favors a $12 FEDERAL minimum BECAUSE that FLOOR has broad support among Democrats in Congress and is a large increase over the current $7.25 minimum. Lower-cost markets (e.g., Alabama) likely can't get to the price of markets like NY and CA. If $15 were reasonable number for all states, then NY and CA probably would have gone much higher. Instead, even CA is phasing in the $15 minimum over seven years -- from $10.50 in 2016 to $15 in 2022. NY is phasing in the increase to $15 over three years, and that's only in NYC. It will take longer in the rest of NY state. I know the NY Times is taking a lot of heat from the Berners in the comments section, but that's no excuse for manufacturing dilemmas to pander to their simplistic point of view.
Kasich is almost as backward-looking as Cruz -- he just takes less public glee revelling in sociopathy.
Forward into the 1950's. There is nothing about Kaisich that is forward thinking. Socially he is a caveman.

Yeah, move forward to decimate Roe v Wade and a woman's right to healthcare, to make her own life choices and have say over her very own body. Kasich's record is horrific on women's autonomy and right to chose. And there's an empty seat on SCOTUS, so this is not hyperbole.

The real problem is that if Clinton is elected , this country will be paralyzed.
The republicans blocked every program that Obama proposed, exactly what Senator McConnell said was his goal.
Imagine what they will do to Clinton.
This country is desperate for infrastructure repair, for entitlement changes, and nothing will happen.
On the other hand , neither trump or Cruz should be president. If kasich ran, this country may have a chance to move forward.

Same in California. Our $15 minimum wage won't get to $15 until 2022. That's a hella long time for folks unable to rent shelter and feed families to wait for a livable wage.  Rent may be cheap in rural N. Mexico but it skyrockets here. For the fifth year in a row, my monthly rent on my 500 square foot apartment just went up $400 a month. I'm okay and able to pay but when someone working for $12 an hour now gets rent increases and food always rises, WTH do they do? A parent can't work all the time, kids need parenting and parents need rest.

"... states like New York that have raised their minimum wage to $15 an hour..."

But NY has NOT raised its minimum wage to $15 an hour, even in NYC, etc. It has said that it will, eventually, raise its minimum wage to $15 an hour. It's just misleading to say otherwise.
No, they do not.  You must have her confused with Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz.

Care to give us a few facts to support your assertions? Here are a few to rebut yours:
http://fivethirtyeight.com/datalab/hillary-clinton-was-liberal-hillary-c...

I'll see your link and raise the ante with this one:
http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2015/10/democratic-debate-hillary...

Although one flip flop that isn't mentioned in this article, is one of my favs, concerning how she changed her position on a bankruptcy bill to help the banking industry. Apparently Elizabeth Warren wasn't impressed with this bit of political expediency.

"Big banks were now (after she became Senator) part of Senator Clinton’s constituency. She wanted their support, and they wanted hers—including a vote in favor of ‘that awful bill,’” Warren wrote.

"Mrs. Clinton holds many, though not all, of the same views as Mr. Sanders."
Really, but don't those views change second by second based on polling indicating what she needs to say in order to get elected?

"Hillary Clinton: Bernie Sanders 'has been largely a very reliable supporter of the NRA' "- This claim was rated "mostly false" by Politifact. Sanders has a D minus rating by the NRA. So, if they have bought him, they didn't get very much for their money. This is a bogus claim.
Stop calling Clinton a Republican. It's not a tenable position and amounts to name-calling.

Serna, if Clinton is a such a plutocratic sellout to Wall Street, why is the GOP, the Party of plutocrats, oligarchs and corporatists, desperately trying to rip HER apart while they offer only smiles and praise for Bernie the honest anti-1%-er??

How can that possibly fit into the picture you've drawn? I think the GOP knows who its real enemy is. You, not so much.
I agree, except that canceling your subscription is rash. People forget that the NYT has its prerogative in supporting whomever they want for pres.

That's it NYT. I give up.  You endorsed her. You then proceeded to tell her to be more like Bernie Sanders, as you do here again.  I am not for Sanders because I am deluded. I am for Sanders because she is, essentially, a Republican. She is a hawk who will lead the U.S. into more endless wars, whose regard for women and children stop at the borders of the U.S., and who will not discipline Walll Street because she is of Wall Street.  I, like the public editor who is on her way to Washington, enjoy reading the NYT's culture and arts coverage, but I have had enough of your support of HRC's presumption that she will be President.  Canceling my subscription in the morning.

Em7282: if Dems stay home in November, as they did in 2010, and the election goes to the other side, you think apathy would not be to blame? Even a "lesser" Democratic candidate has it all over any Republican in what they will be working towards. Millennials are right to support Bernie's ideas but they are wrong if they think that a President alone can effect the changes they desire or that allowing a Republican to win will "show" everyone that they were right. The Obama Presidency is evidence of the inability of a president alone to get a platform passed into law.

And think about the SCOTUS, a conservative Justice will move the law into the 19th century just as you want progress on social and economic issues. Taking your marbles and going home leaves the playground to the bullies. It takes more than enthusiasm to change a government and a direction; it takes real grit over many years. Young people have the years, but will you have the grit?

here comes the new york times reminding New Yorkers that they don't really have to vote because the future has been determined already. When Democrats stay home in November and they have to report on Clinton's crushing defeat, they'll blame voter apathy.

The NYT disgraces itself with theiir continued obsession with a failed secretary of state who enabled her misogynistic abusive husband for 8+ years.
What do you tell your daughters!

Women didn't fight for the obligation to condemn and ditch their misbehaving.  husbands.  We fought for the right to make our own decisions in this and other matters.  If Hillary wanted to continue her marriage to Bill, she had every right to do that and she shouldn't be criticized for it.  The belief of some who don't like Hillary that she ought to have divorced Bill is just as much a prison as the old view that a woman must remain in a marriage no matter whet.  In fact, those who attach special importance to marriage should applaud her choice.
Stating this doesn't make it so, but if you want to vote against Hillary, enabling a GOP president, at least do it for real reasons.

Hillary is obviously the NYT favorite despite her lack-luster record of accomplishment and her trail of misjudgments on Iraq, Libya, Syria.  It may be that her only qualification is being a woman, although her record of covering up husband Bill's peculations should make a shambles of her standing up for women's rights.

Do you idealists understand that losing the White House would be a political disaster for this country and yourselves that would take literally decades, if ever, to overcome?  Do you understand the opportunity that Scalia's death has unexpectedly opened, and that the Notorious RBG, bless her heart, cannot live and adjudicate forever, nor can Kennedy and Thomas?  The Democrats MUST maintain ownership of the Presidency, and we must all agree to vote for either Hillary or Bernie no matter who wins the nomination.  Allowing Trump or Cruz or any other Republican to attain the presidency is simply unthinkable, period.
It's not just the young, some us, many of us older people get it too.

Seriously? Bernie Sanders, who has spent a lifetime in government and decades in Congress, offers something NEW? I think Millennial voters are in a social media bubble. There are millions of Democrats who are happy with Clinton as their nominee.

The rift in the Dem party is not a schism caused by loud and harsh campaigning; it's a schism caused by the birth of something brand new from the heart of the ossified, obsolete old:

To millions of Democrats, 80% of Millennials, and 70% of Independents, Hillary Clinton stands for the OLD, third-way, elitist, 1% Democratic Party which will spend ZERO time worrying about their issues, because it's too busy creating tax loopholes and eviscerating regulations for its billionaire donors.

Bernie represents a NEW political zeitgeist, taking place all over the western world, that the Age of Selfishness and Greed had got to end: it's time for us to realize we're all in this together.

The MSM, including the NYT, has abandoned its proper role as a reporter of news, and has opted instead to influence and create the news it wants: a continuation of the same intolerable income inequality that is ruining this country and driving millions into poverty and despair.

The DNC and Dem Party would do well to realize that these differences of ideas won't be papered over just to put a blue candidate into the White House. Many many Bernie supporters will not vote for her under any circumstances. He, in fact, is the more viable candidate, but the Power Elite are insisting on one of their own.

Their actions might not only lose the White House, but spell the end of the Democratic Party while the new, young, progressive, Independent voters form their own party.

re: Larry Figdill: " Of course, it's likely that she said some friendly things, since she was their guest."

With all due respect: Since when do guests get *paid* for appearing? No one has ever paid me for coming over for dinner and a chat.
